content: The "Juvenile Criminal Act of 1994" amends the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 to focus on identifying hardcore youths for transfer to the adult criminal justice system. The Juvenile Criminal Act of 1994 amends the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 to assist State and local governments in identifying hardcore juvenile offenders for removal from the juvenile justice system. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to require the prosecution of juveniles aged 14 and older as adults for serious offenses like murder, robbery, battery, and rape while armed with a firearm. Juveniles aged 14 and older can be prosecuted as adults for serious offenses including murder, robbery, battery, rape with a firearm, or if they engage in activities that could lead to imprisonment exceeding 1 year for the fourth time. Transfer to juvenile justice system can be considered on a case-by-case basis if deemed in the interest of justice under State law. Juveniles aged 14 and older can be prosecuted as adults for serious offenses. Transfer to juvenile justice system can be considered on a case-by-case basis if deemed in the interest of justice under State law. Recordkeeping regarding juveniles is required. Section 223(a) of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for recordkeeping of juveniles adjudicated for certain offenses, ensuring equivalent records to adult convictions are kept for a specified period of time. The amendment to the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 requires that juveniles adjudicated for certain offenses have their fingerprints and photographs sent to the FBI, with their information transmitted to the FBI including name, birth date, date of adjudication, and disposition. SEC. 6. FINANCIAL INCENTIVE. Amends Section 223(c)(3) of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 to change the percentage requirement. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF AMENDMENTS. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the enactment date, with exceptions for fiscal years before January 1, 1995. Certain amendments will not apply to states until after the first fiscal year following the State legislature's session after the Act's enactment.
